0.question:
Tom got a new car stereo. He was trying it out. He drove around with it cranked up. Tom was eventually pulled over. He explained what happened but still got ticketed.
Which is more likely?
(a) Tom would pay the ticket.
(b) Tom would pay the ticket so that he could have dinner with his friends later that evening.
0.init_model_answer:
The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes additional information about Tom having dinner with his friends. However, this added detail makes it less likely, not more, because it's a conjunction (combination) of two events, both of which must occur.

So, the more likely option is (a) Tom would pay the ticket. This is the simpler and more general scenario, and thus has a higher probability of occurring.

1.question:
James had a child when he was very young. Although he struggled, he wanted to be a good dad. James made sure his child had everything she needed. He worked 2 jobs everyday. James and his kid were very close.
Which is more likely?
(a) James would spend quality time with his child whenever possible.
(b) James would spend quality time with his child whenever possible so that he could catch up on his favorite TV shows later.
1.target_answer: (a) James would spend quality time with his child whenever possible
1.init_model_answer:
The Linda Problem, or conjunction fallacy, is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes the condition of James wanting to catch up on his favorite TV shows later. However, this added detail does not necessarily make it more likely than option (a), which is a more general statement about James spending quality time with his child.

Therefore, based on the information provided and the concept of the conjunction fallacy, option (a) is more likely. James spending quality time with his child whenever possible is a general statement and does not include any additional conditions.

2.question:
Jackson was in class listening to his teacher's lesson. Their new assignment was a report on their favorite animal. Jackson immediately knew he wanted to cover tigers. He spent all weekend researching tigers and even visited the zoo. His paper got a fantastic grade and entertained all of his classmates.
Which is more likely?
(a) Jackson might choose to write more reports on other animals or subjects he enjoys.
(b) Jackson might choose to write more reports on other animals or subjects he enjoys so that he can learn to bake chocolate chip cookies.
2.target_answer: (a) Jackson might choose to write more reports on other animals or subjects he enjoys
2.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) Jackson might choose to write more reports on other animals or subjects he enjoys.

The reason is that option (a) is a simple and straightforward possibility based on Jackson's interest in writing reports about subjects he enjoys, as evidenced by his experience with the tiger report.

Option (b), on the other hand, introduces an unrelated element (learning to bake chocolate chip cookies) that is not suggested or implied by the information given about Jackson. This makes it a less probable scenario, and thus, less likely than option (a). This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where the specific conditions in option (b) make it appear less likely than the general conditions in option (a), even though option (b) includes all the conditions of option (a) and more.

3.question:
A fan ran onto the field Monday night at the 49ers game. He interrupted game action with a jaunt that lasted about a minute. Players stopped and watched as security ended up tackling him. He was later handcuffed and detained but not arrested. He was a minor, only 17 years old.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely run onto the sports field during a game.
(b) The protagonist would likely run onto the sports field during a game so that he could promote a new brand of gardening tools.
3.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely run onto the sports field during a game
3.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) The protagonist would likely run onto the sports field during a game.

This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, which is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific than option (a), as it includes the additional detail about promoting a new brand of gardening tools. However, this added detail makes option (b) less likely, not more, because it requires two conditions to be true instead of just one. Therefore, option (a) is more likely.

4.question:
I am Chinese. One day an eight year old boy made fun of my race. I stopped my bike and went to the boy. I offered to rearrange his face. He ran away, scared.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist might continue riding their bike.
(b) The protagonist might continue riding their bike so that they can enjoy the nice weather.
4.target_answer: (a) The protagonist might continue riding their bike
4.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) The protagonist might continue riding their bike.

This is because option (a) is more general and includes a wider range of possibilities. Option (b) is more specific and includes additional details that may or may not be true. The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, we should not assume that the protagonist was riding their bike to enjoy the nice weather, as this detail was not provided in the original problem. Therefore, option (a) is more likely.

5.question:
Every day when Ellen woke up, she exercised for twenty minutes. She needed it to feel energized to face her day. When one day she overslept, she had to skip her exercises. As she wasn't energized enough, she chose the wrong bus. It took her an hour to realize her mistake and arrived late at work.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist, Ellen, would likely try to find time later in the day to exercise.
(b) The protagonist, Ellen, would likely try to find time later in the day to exercise so that she could update her music playlist.
5.target_answer: (a) The protagonist, Ellen, would likely try to find time later in the day to exercise
5.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) The protagonist, Ellen, would likely try to find time later in the day to exercise.

The reason is that option (a) is more likely because it is a single event, while option (b) is a conjunction of two events: Ellen finding time to exercise and updating her music playlist. The probability of two events happening together (a conjunction) is always less than or equal to the probability of either one happening alone. This is known as the conjunction fallacy, a logical fallacy that occurs when it is assumed that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, the specific condition (Ellen exercising and updating her playlist) is less probable than the general one (Ellen exercising).

6.question:
Stanley is visiting his doctor. His doctor tells him he has high blood pressure. Stanley decides to go on vacation. He heads to Hawaii. He spends a few weeks relaxing in Hawaii and lowers his blood pressure.
Which is more likely?
(a) Stanley would continue managing his health proactively.
(b) Stanley would continue managing his health proactively so that he can learn to speak Hawaiian fluently.
6.target_answer: (a) Stanley would continue managing his health proactively
6.init_model_answer:
The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes the condition of Stanley wanting to learn to speak Hawaiian fluently in addition to managing his health proactively.

However, the probability of two independent events occurring together (Stanley managing his health proactively AND Stanley wanting to learn Hawaiian) is always less than or equal to the probability of either one occurring alone.

Therefore, the correct answer, avoiding the conjunction fallacy, is (a) Stanley would continue managing his health proactively.

7.question:
I was in the shower. I had just finished lathering the shampoo. The water stopped. No other water in the house worked. I called a plumber, then went next door to wash out my hair.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely use their neighbor's shower to rinse out the shampoo.
(b) The protagonist would likely use their neighbor's shower to rinse out the shampoo so that they could check the neighbor’s brand of shampoo for comparison.
7.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely use their neighbor's shower to rinse out the shampoo
7.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) The protagonist would likely use their neighbor's shower to rinse out the shampoo. This is because it directly addresses the problem at hand (needing to rinse out the shampoo), while option (b) adds an unnecessary detail (checking the neighbor's brand of shampoo for comparison), making it less probable. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

8.question:
Two of my coworkers in the office had an affair. The man's wife found out. He stopped the affair and promised to be faithful. His wife made up a FB page in his name. She tried to catch him cheating on Facebook, but he has been good.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist (the man’s wife) would likely continue to monitor the fake Facebook page closely.
(b) The protagonist (the man’s wife) would likely continue to monitor the fake Facebook page closely so that she can improve her photography skills.
8.target_answer: (a) The protagonist (the man’s wife) would likely continue to monitor the fake Facebook page closely
8.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) The protagonist (the man’s wife) would likely continue to monitor the fake Facebook page closely. This is because the wife created the fake Facebook page to monitor her husband's activities, not to improve her photography skills. Therefore, it is more likely that she would continue to use it for its intended purpose. Option (b) is an example of a conjunction fallacy, where a specific condition (improving her photography skills) is added to a general scenario (monitoring the fake Facebook page), making it less probable.

9.question:
Henry the clown wasn't a very good clown name. On the paper in front of Henry was a list of 20 names all crossed out. Despair was slowly settling over Henry. Inspiration suddenly descended upon Henry. Heckles was the perfect clown name for Henry.
Which is more likely?
(a) Henry would write "Heckles" at the top of his list of clown names.
(b) Henry would write "Heckles" at the top of his list of clown names so that he could remember to buy groceries later.
9.target_answer: (a) Henry would write "Heckles" at the top of his list of clown names
9.init_model_answer: The more likely option is (a) Henry would write "Heckles" at the top of his list of clown names. This is because the story provides context that Henry is focused on finding a clown name, and "Heckles" is the perfect name he thought of. Option (b) is less likely as it introduces an unrelated action (buying groceries) that was not mentioned or suggested in the original context. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people may incorrectly assume that specific conditions (Henry writing the name to remember groceries) are more probable than general ones (Henry simply writing the name).

10.question:
James tried to arrange a date Nancy. She wasn't interested and clearly told him. He didn't listen and decided to follow her around school. She got scared and reported him to the school. James went missing for a few days but was eventually found.
Which is more likely?
(a) James would likely apologize to Nancy.
(b) James would likely apologize to Nancy so that he could borrow her notes for the chemistry class.
10.target_answer: (a) James would likely apologize to Nancy
10.init_model_answer:
The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes the detail about borrowing Nancy's chemistry notes. However, this added detail makes it less likely, not more, because it's an additional condition that must be true.

Therefore, the more likely scenario is (a) James would likely apologize to Nancy. This is a broader, more general statement that doesn't require additional conditions to be true.

11.question:
Tom's car was having problems. He took it to several mechanics. None were able to help him. Eventually Tom asked a knowledgeable friend about it. The friend was able to send him down the right path.
Which is more likely?
(a) Tom likely followed his friend's advice regarding his car issue.
(b) Tom likely followed his friend's advice regarding his car issue so that he could improve his cooking skills.
11.target_answer: (a) Tom likely followed his friend's advice regarding his car issue
11.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) Tom likely followed his friend's advice regarding his car issue.

This is because the second option (b) includes additional specific information that is not necessary and makes it less probable. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, which is the assumption that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, the specific condition of Tom wanting to improve his cooking skills is added to the scenario, making it less likely than the more general scenario of Tom simply following his friend's advice about his car.

12.question:
Jason was working hard. He was trying to craft a perfect song. He wrote down the lyrics. Jason practiced his song on his guitar many times. He was finally happy with it and thought that it might even be a hit.
Which is more likely?
(a) Jason would perform his song in front of an audience or record it.
(b) Jason would perform his song in front of an audience or record it so that he could learn how to cook Italian food.
12.target_answer: (a) Jason would perform his song in front of an audience or record it
12.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Jason would perform his song in front of an audience or record it.

This is because option (a) includes only one condition (Jason performing or recording his song), while option (b) includes two conditions (Jason performing or recording his song AND learning how to cook Italian food). The probability of two events happening together (conjunction) is always lower than the probability of each event happening individually. This is known as the conjunction fallacy. The story provided does not give any indication that Jason is interested in learning how to cook Italian food, so there's no reason to assume that this would affect his likelihood of performing or recording his song.

13.question:
Jamillah always wanted to be a lawyer. She went to college and studied hard day and night. Passing the bar exam meant she could take care of her mom. The day of the test, Jamilah's stomach was in knots. After reading the letter from the law firm, she hugged her mom.
Which is more likely?
(a) Jamillah would apply for a job at the law firm.
(b) Jamillah would apply for a job at the law firm so that she could adopt a new puppy.
13.target_answer: (a) Jamillah would apply for a job at the law firm
13.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) Jamillah would apply for a job at the law firm.

The reason is that the event described in option (a) is simpler and more general than the event in option (b). Option (b) includes all the elements of option (a), but adds an additional condition (that she would adopt a new puppy). This makes option (b) a conjunction of two events, both of which must occur for the statement to be true.

The probability of a conjunction of events is always less than or equal to the probability of any of the individual events. Therefore, it's less likely that both events in option (b) would occur than that the single event in option (a) would occur. This is known as the conjunction fallacy, where people often assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

14.question:
Katherine loved coffee. Her students gave her a Starbucks Gift Certificate. She was so excited to use it! The next day, she went through the drive-through. She felt very loved when she used the gift certificate.
Which is more likely?
(a) Katherine would buy coffee at Starbucks using the gift certificate.
(b) Katherine would buy coffee at Starbucks using the gift certificate so that she could watch the season finale of her favorite TV show later that evening.
14.target_answer: (a) Katherine would buy coffee at Starbucks using the gift certificate
14.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Katherine would buy coffee at Starbucks using the gift certificate.

This is because option (a) is a simple, single event, while option (b) is a conjunction of two events: Katherine buying coffee and Katherine watching her favorite TV show. According to the rules of probability, the likelihood of two events happening together (a conjunction) is always less than or equal to the likelihood of either event happening individually. Therefore, it's more likely that Katherine would just buy coffee at Starbucks using the gift certificate than the specific scenario where she buys coffee to watch her favorite TV show. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people often assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

15.question:
My granddaughter was born premature. She only weighed one pound and six ounces at birth. She was so premature that she was considered to be a micro preemie. We were very worried that she would survive. Thankfully she did, and is now two years old.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely celebrate their granddaughter's second birthday.
(b) The protagonist would likely celebrate their granddaughter's second birthday so that they could discuss their plans for upcoming vacation.
15.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely celebrate their granddaughter's second birthday
15.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) The protagonist would likely celebrate their granddaughter's second birthday.

This is because option (a) is a simple, standalone event that directly follows the context given in the story. It does not include any extra conditions or specific details that would make it less likely to occur.

Option (b), on the other hand, includes an additional condition: discussing plans for an upcoming vacation. This extra detail makes option (b) a specific instance of option (a), and thus less likely to occur. This is known as the conjunction fallacy, where people often mistakenly believe that a specific condition is more probable than a general one. In reality, the probability of two events happening together (the conjunction) is always less than or equal to the probability of each event happening individually.

16.question:
Tim was driving to work on his motorcycle. Tim was unprepared for rain. A huge storm bombarded Tim. Tim had to drive slow in the rain. Tim was late to work.
Which is more likely?
(a) Tim would likely call his workplace to inform them of his delay.
(b) Tim would likely call his workplace to inform them of his delay so that he could ask if anyone wanted coffee.
16.target_answer: (a) Tim would likely call his workplace to inform them of his delay
16.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Tim would likely call his workplace to inform them of his delay.

This is because option (a) is a single event, while option (b) is a conjunction of two events: Tim calling his workplace and Tim asking if anyone wants coffee. According to the principles of probability, the conjunction of two events is always less likely than either of the individual events. This is known as the conjunction fallacy, a cognitive bias in which people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

17.question:
I used to use iTunes, but decided it was too limited. After finding a better music service, I tried to transfer over files. ITunes wouldn't let me transfer my music. I had to reformat all of my music to get it to work anywhere else. Even after I did that, nearly a quarter of my music was missing.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely search for a software or service that can successfully convert and transfer all their music files.
(b) The protagonist would likely search for a software or service that can successfully convert and transfer all their music files so that they can start a new garden in their backyard.
17.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely search for a software or service that can successfully convert and transfer all their music files
17.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) The protagonist would likely search for a software or service that can successfully convert and transfer all their music files. This is because the problem described is directly related to transferring music files, and there's no mention or indication of a desire to start a new garden. Option (b) is an example of a conjunction fallacy, where an unnecessary condition ("so that they can start a new garden in their backyard") is added, making it less probable than the simpler option (a).

18.question:
Allie needed some batteries. She needed portable ones. She was happy to buy them. She got good usage out of them. They lasted a long time.
Which is more likely?
(a) Allie would go to a store to buy more batteries.
(b) Allie would go to a store to buy more batteries so that she could ask for directions to the nearest library.
18.target_answer: (a) Allie would go to a store to buy more batteries
18.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Allie would go to a store to buy more batteries.

The reason is that option (a) is a simple, straightforward statement about Allie's likely behavior, based on the information given about her need for batteries. Option (b), on the other hand, includes additional details that make it less likely, not more. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people sometimes assume that a more detailed scenario is more likely than a simpler one, even though adding details actually makes a scenario less likely to occur. In this case, there's no information given to suggest that Allie needs to go to the library, so there's no reason to assume she would ask for directions to one while buying batteries.

19.question:
Phil was driving down the highway. He was hearing a weird noise from his engine. It was a ticking noise. Phil's car started to smoke. He pulled over to the side of the road and waited for help.
Which is more likely?
(a) Phil would call a mechanic or roadside assistance.
(b) Phil would call a mechanic or roadside assistance so that they could recommend a good restaurant nearby.
19.target_answer: (a) Phil would call a mechanic or roadside assistance
19.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) Phil would call a mechanic or roadside assistance. This is because the second option (b) includes additional specific details that are not necessarily related to the situation described, making it less probable. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people often assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

20.question:
Greg was eating at a restaurant. But his meal was so large. He quickly became full. But he wanted to finish his meal. Greg realized it would have been better not to finish it.
Which is more likely?
(a) Greg would likely take the remaining portion of his meal to go.
(b) Greg would likely take the remaining portion of his meal to go so that he could discuss a new book he was reading with his friend later.
20.target_answer: (a) Greg would likely take the remaining portion of his meal to go
20.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) Greg would likely take the remaining portion of his meal to go.

The reason is that option (a) is a simple, single action that Greg could take, while option (b) is a conjunction of two events: Greg taking his meal to go AND discussing a new book with his friend later. The probability of two events happening together (a conjunction) is always less than or equal to the probability of either event happening individually. This is known as the conjunction fallacy, which is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

In this case, the specific condition (taking the meal to go AND discussing a book) is less likely than the general one (taking the meal to go). Therefore, option (a) is more likely.

21.question:
Tom bragged to all his American friends about his amazing beach life in Mexico. His friends didn't like the blowhard, but loved having his friendship. Then the United States elected a xenophobic President. He built a giant wall to keep everyone in Mexico out. The giant wall kept Tom out, too.
Which is more likely?
(a) Tom would likely try to contact his friends for help or support to return to the United States.
(b) Tom would likely try to contact his friends for help or support to return to the United States so that he could watch his favorite American TV shows more easily.
21.target_answer: (a) Tom would likely try to contact his friends for help or support to return to the United States
21.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) Tom would likely try to contact his friends for help or support to return to the United States. This is because it is a broader and more basic need for Tom to want to return to his home country, especially after being unable to do so due to the construction of the wall. Option (b) is a specific reason (wanting to watch his favorite American TV shows more easily) that is included within the broader scenario of Tom wanting to return to the United States, making it less likely. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where a specific scenario is perceived as more likely than a broader one, even though the specific scenario is contained within the broader one.

22.question:
Harry is a 78 year old retired professor. He is rather arrogant and thinks he knows everything. Harry had been away on vacation but just returned. The concierge told me Harry had gotten into 3 fights already. I was amused and amazed.
Which is more likely?
(a) Harry would likely start another argument or dispute with someone.
(b) Harry would likely start another argument or dispute with someone so that he can choose what to have for dinner.
22.target_answer: (a) Harry would likely start another argument or dispute with someone
22.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Harry would likely start another argument or dispute with someone.

The reason is that option (a) is more probable because it only requires one condition to be met: Harry starting an argument. This is consistent with the information given about Harry's character and his previous behavior.

Option (b), on the other hand, is an example of the conjunction fallacy. It includes two conditions that must both be true: Harry starting an argument and doing so specifically to choose what to have for dinner. The second condition is not suggested by the information given and makes the scenario less likely, not more. Therefore, even though (b) is more specific, it is less likely to occur than (a).

23.question:
My sister-in-law Hilda is a smoker. We used to go to NH to visit friends often. There was no tax on cigarettes in NH, as opposed to MA. Hilda asked me to buy her a carton of cigarettes to save money. I did so, but she never paid me for the cigarettes.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely ask Hilda to pay for the cigarettes.
(b) The protagonist would likely ask Hilda to pay for the cigarettes so that she could use the extra money to buy a new plant for her garden.
23.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely ask Hilda to pay for the cigarettes
23.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) The protagonist would likely ask Hilda to pay for the cigarettes.

This is because option (a) is a simple, single event probability, while option (b) is a conjunction of two events: the protagonist asking for the money and then using that money to buy a new plant for her garden. The probability of two events occurring together (a conjunction) is always less than or equal to the probability of either one occurring alone. This is the essence of the conjunction fallacy.

24.question:
I once had a great corporate job. One day I decided I wanted to move to live my dream. I walked off of my job during a lunch break. Everyone from the job tried to call me for days. I had everything that I could fit in my car and I drove for two days.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely start a new life in a different place or pursue a personal dream or passion.
(b) The protagonist would likely start a new life in a different place or pursue a personal dream or passion so that they could learn to play the accordion.
24.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely start a new life in a different place or pursue a personal dream or passion
24.init_model_answer: The more likely scenario is (a) The protagonist would likely start a new life in a different place or pursue a personal dream or passion. This option is more probable because it is broader and does not specify a particular dream or passion, such as learning to play the accordion. The second option (b) is a specific subset of the first option, and therefore less likely due to the conjunction fallacy, which is the assumption that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

25.question:
Aya opened her windows for spring cleaning. She loved the fresh scent. Then a bird flew inside! Aya was startled! She had to shoo it out with a broom.
Which is more likely?
(a) Aya would close the windows after shooing out the bird.
(b) Aya would close the windows after shooing out the bird so that she could listen to her favorite music without outside noise.
25.target_answer: (a) Aya would close the windows after shooing out the bird
25.init_model_answer: The correct answer is (a) Aya would close the windows after shooing out the bird. This option is more likely because it is a single event and does not include additional specific conditions like listening to her favorite music without outside noise. The second option (b) is an example of the conjunction fallacy, which is the assumption that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

26.question:
Derek stopped at a four way intersection. As soon as he continued driving, another car accelerated. It collided with Derek's car. Although he was dizzy, he tried to get out of the car. He managed to escape and called the cops for support.
Which is more likely?
(a) Derek would wait for the police to arrive and assess the situation.
(b) Derek would wait for the police to arrive and assess the situation so that he could ask them about the weather forecast for the next day.
26.target_answer: (a) Derek would wait for the police to arrive and assess the situation
26.init_model_answer:
The more likely scenario is (a) Derek would wait for the police to arrive and assess the situation. This is because it is a simple and straightforward outcome based on the information provided, which states that Derek called the cops for support after the accident.

Option (b) is an example of a conjunction fallacy, where an additional specific condition (Derek asking the police about the weather forecast for the next day) is added to the initial event, making it seem less probable. The conjunction fallacy occurs when people assume that specific conditions are more likely to occur than general ones. In reality, the probability of two events occurring together (Derek waiting for the police and asking them about the weather) is lower than the probability of a single event (Derek waiting for the police).

27.question:
Margaret and Truman were discussing what kind of house to buy. Margaret wanted to get a townhouse near the coast. Truman wanted to get a cottage near the campgrounds. They found a cottage-like house that was right on the water. They decided to compromise and secured a loan for the house.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely move into the cottage-like house near the water.
(b) The protagonist would likely move into the cottage-like house near the water so that they could be closer to a top-rated sushi restaurant.
27.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely move into the cottage-like house near the water
27.init_model_answer:
The more likely option is (a) The protagonist would likely move into the cottage-like house near the water.

This is because the story provides no information about a top-rated sushi restaurant or any preference the protagonists have for sushi. Therefore, adding this extra condition in option (b) makes it less likely, as it introduces an unmentioned and unnecessary specificity. This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

28.question:
Don wanted a pair of boots. He already had a few pairs. He decided to treat himself to another. He was excited when he found a sale. Don bought his boots and wore them the next day.
Which is more likely?
(a) Don would show off his new boots.
(b) Don would show off his new boots so that he could feel more prepared for a potential snowstorm.
28.target_answer: (a) Don would show off his new boots
28.init_model_answer: The more likely option is (a) Don would show off his new boots. This is because it is a simple and straightforward possibility based on the information given. Option (b) includes additional specific conditions (feeling more prepared for a potential snowstorm) that are not suggested or implied in the information provided, making it less likely due to the conjunction fallacy.

29.question:
Jeremy and jordan have an apartment together. They started hating each other. They stopped talking to each other. They decided to move out. Now they live separately.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely start settling into their new living situation.
(b) The protagonist would likely start settling into their new living situation so that they can start collecting rare tropical fish.
29.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely start settling into their new living situation
29.init_model_answer:

30.question:
Charles went on Craig's List to find a girlfriend. He saw a picture of a girl in a bikini. He e-mailed her and they arranged a date. Charles picked her up and she had massive buttons all over her. Charles was mad, she was a button freak, with 500 buttons on her.
Which is more likely?
(a) Charles would likely end the date early or avoid further contact with her.
(b) Charles would likely end the date early or avoid further contact with her so that he can get home in time to water his plants.
30.target_answer: (a) Charles would likely end the date early or avoid further contact with her
30.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Charles would likely end the date early or avoid further contact with her.

This is because option (a) is more probable than option (b). Option (b) is a specific subset of option (a), meaning it includes the additional condition of Charles wanting to get home to water his plants. This additional detail makes option (b) less likely, as it requires two conditions to be true (Charles ending the date early and him wanting to water his plants), while option (a) only requires one condition to be true (Charles ending the date early). This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people tend to assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

31.question:
Tony loves music. He learns how to play several instruments at a young age. He spends all his free time listening to and playing music. Tony goes to college for music production. Tony is now a famous music producer.
Which is more likely?
(a) Tony would attend a music concert.
(b) Tony would attend a music concert so that he can review the latest smartphone models being used by concertgoers.
31.target_answer: (a) Tony would attend a music concert
31.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Tony would attend a music concert.

The reason is that the statement (a) is more general and includes a wider range of possibilities. It only suggests that Tony would attend a music concert, which is highly likely given his love for music.

On the other hand, statement (b) is more specific and includes additional conditions that must be true for the statement to be true. It suggests that not only would Tony attend a music concert, but he would do so specifically to review the latest smartphone models being used by concertgoers. This is less likely given the information provided about Tony, which focuses solely on his love for music and does not mention any interest in smartphones.

Therefore, based on the information provided, it is more likely that Tony would attend a music concert (option a) than that he would attend a music concert specifically to review the latest smartphone models being used by concertgoers (option b). This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people tend to assume that specific conditions are more likely to occur than general ones.

32.question:
Sadie was at school when she heard a boy cry. She looked and saw he was surrounded by a bunch of kids. In front of the group one kid was making fun of the boy loudly. Sadie told the kid that he was a bully. Luckily, this made the kid and his friends storm off.
Which is more likely?
(a) Sadie would comfort the boy who was crying.
(b) Sadie would comfort the boy who was crying so that she could borrow his pencil afterward.
32.target_answer: (a) Sadie would comfort the boy who was crying
32.init_model_answer: The correct answer is (a) Sadie would comfort the boy who was crying. This is because it is a more general statement and does not include any additional specific conditions like in option (b). The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones, which is not the case. So, the probability of Sadie comforting the boy who was crying is higher than the probability of Sadie comforting the boy who was crying for a specific reason (to borrow his pencil afterward).

33.question:
I went to the mall yesterday. I thought there was a sale. So I showed up at the store. There was no sale. I was so upset.
Which is more likely?
(a) The protagonist would likely leave the mall.
(b) The protagonist would likely leave the mall so that they could check the weather forecast for the next day.
33.target_answer: (a) The protagonist would likely leave the mall
33.init_model_answer:
The conjunction fallacy is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes additional details about checking the weather forecast for the next day. However, these added details make it less likely, not more, because they introduce another condition that must be true.

Therefore, the more likely scenario is option (a): The protagonist would likely leave the mall. This option is more general and does not include any additional conditions that must be true.

34.question:
The last thing Jen remembered was picking up the hitchhiker. Now she was strapped to a hard steel gurney. Jen realized she could feel her face. Her kidnapper held up her skin he'd cut off it. Jen began to scream, and didn't stop.

(b) The protagonist is likely to attempt to escape from her captor so that she can watch her favorite TV show when she gets home.
34.target_answer: (a) The protagonist is likely to attempt to escape from her captor

This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where a specific condition (a and b) is seen as more probable than a general one (a).

35.question:

The conjunction fallacy occurs when people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, the general scenario (a) is more likely than the specific scenario (b).

36.question:
I was curious what is like to be a famous writer like Walter Mosley. I wrote a story about my worst childhood memory. I studied how to put my writing in ebook form. I put story online for sale at two ninety nine a copy. I am now an Amazon dot com best selling author slash writer.

Option (b) is an example of the conjunction fallacy. It is less probable because it includes an additional condition (learning about marine biology) that is not suggested by the information provided. The conjunction fallacy occurs when it is assumed that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, the specific condition (wanting to learn about marine biology) makes the option less likely, not more.

37.question:

This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, which is a cognitive bias where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In this case, option (b) is more specific as it includes an additional detail about Lucy learning to paint landscapes, which makes it less likely than option (a).

38.question:

This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people often assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.

39.question:

This additional condition makes it less likely, as it requires multiple conditions to be true at the same time, hence illustrating the concept of the conjunction fallacy.

41.question:
